Shouldn't the tag be getting itself involved? From the htmlwg it feels very=
 much that when the issue has been raised by anyone but browser vendors the=
mselves it's unlikely to move much further down from what it already has? h=
appy to press on this myself however way is the most effective. 

--
Seb

O=
n 21 Mar 2012, at 17:13, "Julian Reschke" <julian.reschke@...> wrote:

>=
 On 2012-03-21 16:37, Sebastien Lambla wrote:
>> Those are orthogonal conce=
rn. The manifest defines which of the assets
>> ought to be made available =
offline, aka persisted in the cache for a
>> duration that is not tied to t=
he duration of the max-age but of the
>> installed app. *That said*, the be=
havior in deciding to do a conditional
>> request or not based on existing =
caching validation function would make
>> a lot of sense.
>> 
>> More so, i=
t makes a lot of sense for an app that can be used both
>> offline and onli=
ne to have the caching semantics sematics of resources
>> being present and=
 respected, for until a user "installs" the app, the
>> app will react like=
 any HTTP application.
>> 
>> For me, appCache can (and probably ought to) =
simply extend and override
>> the semantics of caching controls to ensure t=
hat whatever caching
>> sematics, the cached (and maybe stale) resource sta=
te is available for
>> however long the application is installed.
>> ...
> =

> Indeed. People over here are not the first ones to notice that :-).
> 
>=
 To make a difference, you should submit feedback to the HTML WG.
> 
> Best=
 regards, Julian
